THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VI.

NOVEMBER 6, 1901.

No. 3.

METHOD IN READING.
S it possible to give a general answer, of any value, to the question, What
shall I read?
The question is not well answered by prescribing a list of books. This
does not allow for individual tastes and for special circumstances, and for that
reason can hardly lead to any valuable result; "Courses of reading" are seldom
followed with profit. Nor is it enough to say simply that one should read what
one finds interesting. This is true, but not the whole truth, for, out of the various things that may interest one, it is desirable to select the most important. Is
it possible to lay down any principles that may guide one in determining what,
at any given stage of intellectual progress, is most suitable to be read?
Most persons would probably agree that, to one who has general cultivation
.
In view, history is of such fundamental importance that it should, especially at
first, form the staple of reading. The mind is interested in facts earlier and
more easily than in abstract thoughts, and hence it is well to begin with history.
Moreover, many subjects cannot be understood without a competent historical
knowledge; no one can study art, literature, politics, philosophy intelligently,
unless he knows something of the development through which they have passed,
and the various conditons of society which, at different times have modified
them. In studying history, one is preparing oneself for the study of many
things. Further, the dispositions, intellectual and moral, which are cultivated
through historical studies are of highest value; "histories make men wise."
During the earlier years of one's self-education, the endeavor should be to gain
a competent knowledge of—at least—Greek, Roman, Mediaeval, English and
American history. In such reading care must be taken not to attempt to force
the memory to retain too much. The writing of abstracts is a valuable aid, and
frequent and patient review is indispensable.
The reading of imaginative literature should go on in connection with historical and biographical reading. One reason for combining th2 two is the
mental relief thus secured. Works of fiction are especially useful as recreation.
After prolonged and serious application, a good novel will restore tone and animation to the mind. Two things should be remembered in regard to novel
reading: first, that it ought to be kept in its place as recreation and not allowed
to usurp time needed for other purposes, and, second, that it should be confined
to books which are really worth one's while. Much time is wasted upon third
and fourth rate stories, which, if expended upon masterpieces, would yield far
more pleasure, as well as vastly more profit.

5

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

The glory of our English literature is in its poetry. This "feigned history" is as important an element of our mental life as actual history. Lord
Bacon well expresses the relation between the two. "Because the acts or events
of true history have not that magnitude which satisfieth the mind of man, poesy
feigneth acts and events greater and more heroical; because true history propoundeth the successes and issues of actions not so agreeable to the merits of
virtue a nd vice, therefore poetry feigns them more just in retribution, and more
according to revealed providence; because true history representeth acts and
events more ordinary and less interchanged, therefore poesy endueth them with
more rareness, and more unexpected and alternative variations." One should
begin with objective and narrative poetry rather than with that which is analytic
and reflective. The early ballads, the Canterbury Tales, Shakspere's histories
and comedies, Goldsmith, Gray, Burns, Scott, Tennyson's Idyls of the Kings,
Longfellow, Whittier—such poetry is more suitable to an unformed taste and
judgment than that of which Wordsworth may be cited as an example. Such
collections as the "Golden Treasury of Songs and Lyrics" are an excellent introduction to the study of poetry. At a later stage of one's growth, the profounder poen y becomes congenial; one learns to find pleasure in metaphysical
refinements and over-subtleties, like those of Robert Browning, which at first
would have been simply incomprehensible.
After a proper basis has been laid for it, what may be called philosophical
reading may be undertaken with profit. By this is meant works of theory and
criticism, which attempt to do more than narrate and describe, which seek to
make generalizations and to search into laws and causes. Every great series of
facts, whether of nature or of man, is capable of being treated both historically
and philosophically, that is, in the way of simple statement and narration, and
also with the design of accounting for the facts and getting at the truths and
laws involved in them. When the latter mode of treatment is adopted, it is
common to use the word philosophy—as we speak of the "philosophy of history," or the "philosophy of art." This department of literature should evidently be reserved until a suitable amount of knowledge has been acquired, and
the powers of reflection and speculation have been properly developed. One is
not qualified to judge the merits of a theory, or a generalization, until one has
become familiar with the facts upon which it rests. The range of possible
reading under this head is, of course, indefinitely wide. A person interested in
nature will naturally pass from simple observation and experiment to the speculative and theoretical aspects of his subject. One familiar with history and literary events and personages will enjoy works of criticism and generalization,
which seek to establish principles of taste, to deduce laws of progress, to compare different eras of civilization. The mental and moral sciences fall under this
category, and also works of political, social,.and theological science. One comes
to studies of this kind at a great advantage, if the mind has been generously
equipped with facts, and the imagination has been trained by familiarity with the
masters of fiction and poetry.
A threefold classification, such as has been suggested, may be of service to
one who is trying to outline a plan of reading with reference, not to acquisition

THE NEWS—LETTER.

3

in a specific field, but to general culture. History, as affording a basis of fact;
imaginative literature, as helping to develop the ideal faculty; philosophy, in a
broad sense, as coordinating and interpretating the phenomena of the world:—
these are the three interests which need to be kept in view, and to be brought
E. H. G.
into harmonious cooperation.

. MEMORIAL EXERCISES TO DR. ROWLAND.
N Saturday, October 26th, the lecture room of the Johns Hopkins physical
laboratory was filled by students and scholars, assembled to hear former
President Mendenhall of Worcester Polytechnic Institute deliver a eulogy
on the late Prof. Henry A. Rowland. Among those present were Mrs. Rowland
and other members of the late Professor's family, Mrs. Huntington Williams,
Dr. Carey T. Hutchinson of New York, and Dr. N. E. Dorsey of Washington,
who were formerly connected with the Johns Hopkins department of physics;
Dr. Wolfe of Washington; Dr. Stratton, the director of the National Bureau of
Standards, and Dr. Barker of Philadelphia. Former President Gilman had a
place in the front row.
President Remsen said, as he introduced Dr. Mendenhall:
"We have already given some expression to the thoughts and feelings Professor Rowland's death aroused in us. We were then, however, too much influenced by our new grief to look at his life work in the broadest way. Our expressions were rather those of personal emotions. We meant to hold a meeting
at which the fuller meaning of his life might be made clear to us. We are receding from him, and the increasing distance gives us clearer view. How great
he was and in what way only a physicist like himself can tell us."
Dr. Mendenhall was then introduced and commenced his address by a reference to Professor Rowland's originality.
"Many of his contemporaries,' he said, "excel him in the quantity of their
works; very, very few of them equal him in its quality. The full value of his
labors may be understood only in the great results to which its quality led other
workers whom his example had stimulated. A complete estimate would demand
reference to nearly all physical investigation of the last quarter of the old century. Quality was his admiration. By this test we will judge his achievements."
With a close knowledge of exact details Dr. Mendenhall then sketched the
development of Dr. Rowland's investigations from an early paper written as a
joke to the Scientific American at the age of 17. The latter part of the address
Was devoted to the personal side of the dead physicist. His characteristics, the
early aptitudes and preferences of the boy, his perseverance and dexterity in applying them under difficulties, the boldness and directness by which he reached
his later results, the severe candor with which he treated his own works and
everybody else's, his underlying kindness of heart, the full devotion with which
he pursued his objects all were outlined in a manner that aroused the highest
admiration of the audience.
After the address Dr. Remsen invited those present to go into one of the
nearby investigation rooms and look over the many inventions of the late
scientist.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

REPRODUCTION OF THE ATHARVA-VEDA.
ROI-4'ESSOR Maurice Bloomfield is in possession of a newly-issued hook
which promises to throw much light on the manners and customs of our
Aryan ancestors many hundreds of years ago. It is a photographic
reproduction, prepared by Professor Bloomfield and Professor Richard Garbe of
Tubingen, of the oldest known manuscript of the Atharva-Veda, one of the
Vedic or sacred books of the Aryan nations. The "Atharva" is the collection
giving the charms, exorcisms, and incantations of the old religion. It tells
how to secure a sweetheart, maintain a happy family, control sickness, and
succeed in business; and it thus gives a most valuable glimpse into the life and
institutions of our oldest known progenitors.
The bringing to light of this volume is due mainly to Professor Von Roth,
of Germany. He realized the insufficiency and corruption of the first edition of
the Atharva; and it was by his energy that the present manuscript was discovered in Srinagar, Kashmir. Professor Roth left the manuscript at his death to
the University of Tubingen.
The manuscript contains about 275 pages of two sheets of birch hark each,
written in an indelible black ink, little faded in the 400 years since the manuscript was written. (The collection contained is, of course, many centuries
older.) Professor Bloomfield hoped that in time a version replacing the native
characters by their English equivalents may be printed, followed by a translation of the text.

T

DR. GILDERSLEEVE AND THE MEMORIAL VOLUME.

t

HE widespread and deeply appreciative tributes of the press on the occasion
of Dr. Basil L. Gildersleeve's seventieth birthday, October 23, are examples of high praise where it is due. Dr. Gildersleeve has combined more
than, perhaps, any other living American, the functions of the tremendously
erudite specialist, and of the broad minded man of letters. This idea of liberal
scholarship he has carried with him throughout his lengthy and many-sided
career.
Dr. Basil Lanneau Gildersleeve was born in Charleston, S. C., October 23,
1831. He took his A. M. at Princeton in 1852, after studying at Charleston
and Washington Jefferson Colleges. In 1856, after several years at Berlin,
Bonn, and Gottingen, he became Professor of Greek at the University of Virginia; and his connection there continued, with a break during his service in
the Civil War, until the foundation of the Johns Hopkins University in 1876.
Honors have showered upon Dr. Gildersleeve for many years, the latest
being the degree of I.,. L. D. presented him by Yale University. But of all
these recognitions, perhaps none has carried to him as much personal good-will
and esteem as will the Memorial Volume now under preparation by a number
of his former students.
This volume will be entitled: "Studies in Honor of Basil Lanneau Gildersleeve." It will contain some 400 pages, consisting of articles by thirty of his

THE NEWS—LETTER.

5

former students at Virginia and Johns Hopkins; and these articles will constitute not only a tribute to Dr. Gildersleeve, but a valuable addition to Greek
philology. Four hundred copies are to be printed by subscription. Dr. M. C.
Sutphen, whose unfortunate death occurred this summer, had charge of the
arrangements for the book. The present committee is composed of Dr. E. H.
Spieker, Dr.. Maurice Bloomfield, Dr. C. W. Emil Miller, Dr. Kirby F. Smith,
Dr. Christopher Johnston, Dr. B. J. Vos, and Dr H. L. Wilson.
On Dr. Gildersleeve's return from Yale, he was presented with a handsome
cathedral clock by the students of his department. The publication of the
Memorial Volume, however, will not take place until Christmas.
MEDAL FROM YALE.

Z

HE Johns Hopkins University last week received from Yale a beautiful
bronze medal, in commemoration of the late bicentennial celebration. In
speaking of the gift President Remsen said that all the leading universities and colleges which were represented in the exercises had received a similar
memorial. The medal was made by Tiffany & Co., N. Y. It is embedded in
a dark leather case, about four inches square, lined with Yale blue silk and
plush. The medal itself is two inches in diameter, and is of the finest workmanship.
On its face is the figure of a victorious Greek, returning in his war
chariot. In front of his restive steeds, a fair goddess waits to place on his brow
the wreath of laurel, Above this scence are the Latin words "Lux et Verztas."
On the other side are two Grecian torches, between which, in raised letters, is
the simple memorial inscription:
Universitas Yalensis
A. D. MDCCCCI
Concelebtat
Collegium Yalense
A. D. MDCCI Conditum.
X PRESIDENT Gilman's address on the second day of the Yale Bicentennial Celebration treated of the relation of Yale to letters and science. In
c- onclusion, he described the spirit of Yale as "living for others, not for
one's self, the greatest happiness in the utmost service." Dr. Welch, professor
of pathology at the Medical School, also spoke,tracing the development of medical progress by Yale professors and graduates. On this occasion, President
Remsen, Dr. Osier, and Dr. Gildersleeve were honored with the degree of
L. L. D., which has already been conferred by Yale upon three other members
of the Faculty—ex-President Gilman, the late Dr. Rowland, and Dr. Welch.

ALL ROOTERS OUT.
N November 16th, the first game for the Maryland Inter-Collegiate foot
ball championship will be played in Baltimore between Western Maryland College and Johns Hopkins. On our trophy-room wall is a space
just large enough for the championship banner; the team is going to try to cover
that space. The team has worked hard and conscientiously, "meds" and
scrubs are out; but so far the rooting has been woefully weak. Weak rooting
does not help bring banners to Hopkins; good, strong rooting is a great
encouragement to the players. Every loyal Hopkins man will be on hand at
both the Western Maryland and St. John's games to help the team struggle.
Every Hopkins man who wants to be called true to his colors must realize that
he is needed at the games. Everybody out, to demonstrate that the enthusiastic
spirit of the last two years is not dead, but dormant.

O

HE gymnasium building is the barometer indicating changes in the temperament, feelings, and conditions of Hopkins men. If trouble is brewing, the
first foam is generally seen in the gym -or cage; if victory is to be celebrated,
the cage is the place where the first yell is given. The locker-room,the cage, the
gymnasium proper are so intimately associated with Hopkins life that the mere
mention generally brings up clear visions !of some of the most i pleasant
incidents of the short three years here. It is also intimately connected with
some of the first impressions—which may not be so pleasant. All the idle
moments at one's command are put in at the gym; and its just in this point that

Z

THE NEWS-LETTER.
the weather indications are shown. If many men loaf around in citizen's garb,
instead of donning undress suits; if they saunter around with pipe in mouth,
and hands in pocket, passing time and criticisms regardless of the value of
either; if their only occupation is to knock,—then something is wrong somewhere. The atmosphere or the people is at fault. That it is not the atmosphere is shown by the notable lack of loafing this year. Very few men come
into the gym building now unless they go in for work. The apparatus upstairs
is being worked hard, the foot ball squad is fairly large, lacrosse and track men
are out, and altogether there is plenty of life all around. Where there is so
much scholastic activity as here, such a state of affairs in athletics is to be
highly commended. The atmosphere is apparently healthy for a general
development.

4 43T's strange I never see any class numerals on fellows over here." A
medical student at Hopkins, who received his A. B. at a large Northern
college, was heard to give expression to these remarks a few days ago.
When the matter is thought over, it does seem strange that within the last few
years the giving of numerals as athletic honors within the classes has been
abandoned. The practice must have been in vogue when the class of 1900 was
here, for many men of that class were seen to wear the red 1901 in "broad display on their manly chests," and on the jerseys of still older men is occasionally
seen the graduating year. Surely, a man who does good work for his class
ought to receive recognition as well as the fellow who is lucky enough to make
the 'Varsity. Where many men strive for few positions, the majority get left;
but why should not the classes remember that it is this majority who bring
victories on class day and rushes? Naughty-two has forgotten this. Think it
over, Juniors and Freshmen.

SENIOR FEED.

t

HE first "Feed" of the Class of '02 is to be held at the Johns Hopkins
Club on the evening of the 16th, after the Western Maryland College
game. Details may be learned from Ogle Marbury, '02. In this connection it is interesting to note a recent address of President Pritchett of the
Boston- "Tech.," in which he strongly advocated just such "stein and pipe"
gatherings, in contrast to the formal dress banquet.
President Pritchett believes in the democratic system of entertainment
found in German universities, where professors and students meet at the frequent "vereins," discussing problems or enjoying more general conversation.
Rich and poor alike gather in good fellowship, each man paying his own score
for beer and tobacco. Thus, says Dr. Pritchett, much sympathetic intercourse
is made possible between the students and also the professors; and he hopes
that his proposed inauguration of such meetings among college students in
Boston will cause a big improvement in college social life.
These free and informal "feeds" are a move in the right direction, one
which must be taken up in turn by '03. Every Hopkins man will welcome a

S.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

8

chance to see more of his classmates, under such reasonable and cheerful
conditions;
"For it's always fair weather,
When good fellows get together,
With a stein on the table.
And a good song ringing clear."

UNDERGRADUATE HAPPENINGS.

t

HE Class of 1902 has decided to present a large settee to the trophy-room.
It is now being made, and will completely fill one of the corners.

The Junior Class officers are: President, H. W. Plaggemeyer; Vice-President, R. C. Hoffman, Jr.; Secretary, J. T. Smith; Treasurer, F. Hazlehurst, Jr.;
Historian, R. S. Lanier; Poet, T. W. Glocker; Orator, J. B. G. Custis, Jr.;
Jester, 5, C. Hopper; Sergeant-at-arms, J. A. Houghton; Captain of Class Foot
Ball Team, F. C. Blauck; Manager, W. H. Matthai; Yell Committee: Lanier,
Bamberger, Pagon, Sandrock and Bird; Flag Committee, Tootle, Baetjer and
Hunley. The following men have been taken into the class organization: F.N.
Iglehart, from '94; Royalle Williams, Lehigh; J. M. Combs, University of
California.
J. S. Grasty has been elected by acclamation to the post of chief rooter,
and is endeavoring to instil into the minds of the Freshmen some slight knowledge of the Hopkins yells. Meetings for practice have been held in the cage,
and it is hoped that '04 will soon make some much-needed improvement in this
direction. They need it.
The first deba"e in the Senate on the benefits of the late strike was not a
shining success. After much talking on both sides, the decision was awarded
to the Ministry's team, which upheld the capitalists' view. The Juniors debated the same question with the same result. The Senior debaters have already
been announced in the NEWS LETTER. The Juniors were: Plaggemeyer,
Smith, Tootle, affirmative; Strayer, Glocker, Blum, negative,
The Freshman Class officers are as follows: President, E. D. Dickey; VicePresident, J. N. Numsen; Secretary, L. G. Wallis; Treasurer, J. R. B. Branch;
Historian, R. S. Opie; Poet, R. S. Licking; Sergeant-at-arms, S. C. Erlanger.
The class colors are black and red.
The strength of the present Freshman Class is 48, as against 55 for last
year. Noughty-three, however, has lost several men this fall, so that the
numbers are not far from equal.
An edict has been issued by the Musical Club's management, requiring all
prospective members of any club to deposit with the leader the sum of $3.00,
which is to be regarded as an advance payment of fines for absence and lateness
at rehearsals. These fines are at the rate of 50 cents for each rehearsal cut and
one cent for every minute late. The money is to be refunded at the end of the
season, less fines collected.

t.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

9

The Glee Club is practising a new Hopkins song, words by W. B. Carver,
to the tune of "Michael Roy." It is a lively marching song, and bids fair to
be the success of the season.
A new scientific organization has been formed, by name the Society of the
Diamond. It was started by a group of biological students, who, finding themselves unable to see some required object in the laboratory, adjourned to procure aid. Subsequent meetings have been held with great benefit. This asso
dation, which is semi-secret in character, is open to scientific students only.

UNIVERSITY NOTES.
N Thursday, Oct. 24, the marriage took place of Mr. Melvin Brandow, assistant librarian of the University, to Miss Ruth Boocock, of New Jersey.

O

Dr. J. M. West, of this city, who took his degree at the Medical School last
June, is about to start for Germany, where he will specialize at various leading
institutions in diseases of the throat.
Dr. Percy L. Kay, recently called to a position in the Treasury Department
of Porto Rico, is the third Hopkins graduate from the history and economics
department to hold a position at the Porto Rican Treasury. The other two are
Dr. J. H. Hollander, who was treasurer of the island, and Dr. T. S. Adams,
whose place Dr. Kay is taking.
Dr. Francisco del Valle, and Dr. Francisco del Valle, Jr., who are attending
courses in the department of history and economics, are graduates of the Institute of San Juan, Porto Rico; the former in 1867, the latter in 1894. In addition, Dr. del Valle is an M. D. of the College of Medicine, Cadiz, 1872, while his
son took his D. D. S. at the Baltimore College of Dental Surgery, and has also
studied law at the University of Maryland.
J. E. Routh, 1900, has been awarded the $250 prize offered by the Century
Magazine for the best essay written by a graduate of any American college or
university. The title of the essay was "Huxley as a Literary Man." Mr.
Routh is at present a graduate student in mathematics and physics.
A letter has been received from the Johns Hopkins Club of the Middle
West, announcing that its second annual session and banquet will be held at
the Hotel Baltimore, Kansas City, Mo., on Friday, November 29. Those finding it possible to attend will notify the secretary, Dr. Chas. Lee Smith, Liberty,
Mo. The officers of the club, which numbers more than 60 members, are as
follows: President, Dr. F. W. Blackmar, University of Kansas; secretary, Dr.
Chas. Lee Smith, William Jewell College, Mo.; vice-presidents, Prof. J. C. Futrall, University of Arkansas; Dr. A. G. Leonard, of Iowa, and Dr. J. White,
University of Nebraska, These officers constitute the Executive Committee.

GALLAUDET, 12—HOPKINS, 0.

t

HE result of our game with Gallaudet was no more than could be expected
with the crippled team which represented Hopkins aturday before last.
Blanck could not be in the game on account of his lame foot. Hill was not
with the team, and Stone was also unable to play. With these three men out of
the game Hopkins did well to hold her silent opponents down to twelve points,
which she did very creditably.
Sharretts kicked off, and Gallaudet was downed with the ball on her fiveyard line. Right at the start Gallaudet showed some superb team work, as her
interference was well nigh invincible, and quickness in starting remarkable.
Erickson made the first dash through left tackle, leaving thirty yards behind him
at the finish; and after an effective mass-play, added ten yards around right end.
By alternating end plays with marvelous success, Gallaudet lanced the pigskin
in the coveted position after six minutes of play. Geilfuss kicked goal.
Sharretts kicked off for Hopkins, and Andree advanced the oval to the fifteen yard line. After two long end runs by Erickson and Andree, Gallaudet
lost the ball for holding; but the Black and Blue were unsuccessful in their attempts at tackle through tackle, so Sayler punted, and by making a touchback
the silent eleven returned the ball from their twenty five yard line Sharretts
caught it and carried it twenty yards on the jump. Then Hopkins unfortunately
lost the oval on downs; and after good gains through guard and around the
ends, Gallaudet tried a drop kick for goal, but failed and Hopkins downed the
ball on her twenty yard line. The Black and Blue now being unable to tear off
more than a yard or two of the required five, Sayler punted. Gallaudet was
forced to do likewise, soon after Sayler returned the kick; and the first half
ended with the ball on Gallaudet's forty yard line.
Gallaudet started the second half with a beautiful kick, and Hopkins
downed the ball on her three yard line. Sayler immdiately punted. After a
couple of good gains through tackle and end Gallaudet was penalized ten yards
for holding, and soon after tried a drop kick. A touchback being made, Sayler
kicked from the twenty-five yard line, and the ball was downed iu the center of
the field. Now with her excellent interference and speedy rushes through the
line and around the ends, Gallaudet soon had the ball behind the goal post.
Geilfuss again kicked goal.

11

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Sharretts kicked off, and after a short gain of five yards the mutes lost the
oval on downs. Hopkins, rather than do likewise, kicked. Thus the second
half ended with the ball in Gallaudet's possession on her fifty yard line.
As was stated the Hopkins team was not its real self in this game. Besides
the three men who were not in it at all, Whipple was knocked out right at the
start. The Black and Blue did well in all their kicks and punts, but showed an
alarming tendency to tackle high, thus allowing their opponents to gain more
ground than they should have. This is mainly on account of the practice in the
Cage, where low tackling would probably produce disastrous results with such
narrow space between the walls. Our fellows were at first rather ineffective at
breaking the opposing interference, but in the second half they did better; and
the line held together wonderfully well against superior weight. The rooting
of Gallaudet was in itself a feature of the game. Actions speak louder than
words. The line up was as follows:

HAVERFORD, 5; HOPKINS, 0
T would have done every rooter's heart good to have seen the great game
which Hopkins put up against Haverford College last Saturday. A pretty
individual play in the shape of a goal from the field was the sole thing

which gives Haverford the right to say that she defeated Hopkins. The

what stuff was in it by forcing Haverford to punt after the second scrimmage.
Towards the end of the half, we rushed the ball down the field by fast, snappy

A touchdown seemed inevitable, and our little band of rooters nearly went wild

Like a drowning man grasping at a straw, Haverford braced, and after

3

1Z

THE NEWS—LETTER.

Sayler, and Blanck smashed the line only to stick, the ball went over to Haverford on downs. The oval had been worked along to that point for a distance of
65 yards only through the greatest determination and effort by every man, and
then to lose it when almost on the goal line—it did, indeed, seem mighty hard
luck. Haverford punted out of danger immediately, and a moment later the
first half ended.
According to a statement made by one of Haverford's men, she fully expected to pile up a score of about 25 points on "Johnny Hopkins." They were
clearly outplayed in the first half, and only by a heroic effort at the last moment
did they prevent Hopkins from scoring. To say that they were both surprised
and piqued would be stating the case very mildly.
In the second half Haverford started in with a grand rush, but Hopkins
continued to be strictly in the game, and almost invariably the home team was
forced to punt for fear of losing the ball on downs. After twelve minutes play,
Haverford's end runs and line rushes seemed to be more effective, and the ball
was advanced to Hopkins 15 yards, which was the nearest she ever got to our
goal line. Then "Johnny" realized that something must be done, and in the
next scrimmage Faris took a kindly hold on the back of the runner's jersey and
snatched him back for just eight yards. The band of Haverford rooters, 250
strong, sent up a deafening yell of encouragement to their team, and the little
hand of Hopkins enthusiasts, six strong, piped out a feeble "Hullabaloo."
Their voices were a little the worse for wear by that time. Captain Grant saw
plainly that he could never carry the ball over Hopkins' goal line, and he
ordered the next best thing. Drinker dropped back to the 30 yard line, and a
moment later received a pretty pass in just the proper place. The ball dropped,
and, as it touched the ground, his toe caught it, and between the posts she
twirled, giving Haverford five points and the game. Hopkins never lost heart,
and a few minutes before the end of the half, she again had the ball on Haverford's 15 yard line. Another reverse of fortune came, however, and she lost the
oval on downs.
In such a battle royal it is difficult to ascribe special honors to any one man.
Every player deserves a hearty slap on the back, and the exclamation, "pretty
work, great work, old man!" Captain Gillespie was naturally disappointed
after such a hard fight, hut both he and Coach Dickson agree in saying that the
team played a truly great game. Next Saturday, Delaware College is to he
played at Wilmington. We are going up to win, and we want a big band of
rooters to see us do it. The teams played as follows:

HE courses of lectures in science and literature, designed primarily for pub
lic school teachers, began on Saturday of last week.

ORIENTAL SEMINARY,—Dr. Foote will give a course of lectures on the
"Literature of the Old Testament," based on the English Bible. Dr. Haupt
will deliver,the introductory lecture, on "How we got our Bible," in the Dillman Room, Wednesday, at 5 o'clock.
The lectures on Public Speaking, given by Mr. S. A. King, M. A., of the
University of London, will be continued on November 6, 11, 15, and 18, at 5
o'clock, in McCoy Hall. Mr. King's first lecture was given Monday.
On Wednesday, the 6th, Dr. Jeffrey R. Brackett, president of the City Supervisors of Charities, will begin a course of lectures on "The Development of
Legislation and Custom Touching Charity and Correction in the United States
and England." The lectures will be held in Levering Hall.
Y. M. C. A. NOTES.
HE courses in Bible Study are in full progress. A class for graduate students meets every Saturday morning at 8.30 to consider special topics selected by the committee in charge, which consists of Mr. D. B. Easter, L.
G. Barret, F. H. Getman. Enrollment, 24. A course for Seniors in the "Acts
and Epistles," led by Mr. J. Gresham Machen, meets at 1 P. M. Wednesdays,
and has an enrollment of 6. The Junior class is under the leadership of Mr.
Horace C. Gillespie, and numbers 7, meeting at firesent at 8.30 A. M., Wednesdays, to consider the same topics followed by the Seniors. This duplication of
the courses results from the fact that there was no Junior Bible class last year.
The Freshman Bible class is in two groups, on account of conflict of hours:
one, led by C. K. Edmunds, meets Thursdays at 10 A. M.; the other, led by R.
S. Licking, meets Thursdays at noon. The enrollment in these two groups is
9, and Sharman's "Life of Christ" is used.
The regular weekly devotional meeting on Tuesday, Oct. 28, was led by
Mr. Don 0. Shelton, International Secretary, who gave a very stimulating Bible
reading in Phillipians.
Mr. A. B. Williams, Jr.,(Yale), Intercollegiate Secretary for the East, addressed the meeting on Tuesday, Nov. 3, and was also present at a conference
of workers Tuesday night at the home of the General Secretary.
The Mission Study class numbers 9, meeting every other Sunday afternoon
at 3.30. Under the direction of Dr. Ballagh, it is proving exceedingly interesting and helpful.
The week beginning Sunday, November 10, will be observed in common
with all religious bodies throughout the country as a "Week of Prayer." There
will be a meeting Sunday afternoon at 4.30, and every day during the week

The Freshman Class at Harvard numbers 553, and at Princeton the entering

At the McMaster University games A. E. Haydon broke the Canadian Col

The oratorical cpntest for the Founder's medal at Vanderbilt University
was won by a Chinaman His subject was: "The Miracle of ' the Twentieth
Century"—the regeneration of China.
The Athletic Association of the University of Colorado has constructed a
fine athletic field 684x242 feet, with a quarter mile track, a grand stand for one
thousand spectators, bath rooms for athletes—all at the foot of a beautiful
mountain.
The University of Pennsylvania has taken the preliminary steps necessary
for the erection of a new medical laboratory, which in point of completeness and
equipment, it is claimed, will be in advance of any similar building now in existence in this country or in Europe.

See the Parrot in his Cage, children! Isn't he just beautiful? Put your
little Fist into the Cage, Johnnie, and try to Pull a feather from his Tail. Don't
scream so frightfully, my Boy: Polly only wanted to Show his Teeth. There,

chewing it, Send it to the Dog for a while, and then Susie will be glad to Chew
it for three Days. Now isn't that lovely?

MOODS.

As the dewdrops glisten and glint and glint,
In the shafts of the light from the eastern hills,
And the air is laden with clover and mint,
Wafted from fields where the mockbird
Where the mockbird warbles and trills and trills,
My heart is elate with the morn, and thrills
All a-quiver with hope and joy without stint,
As the dewdrops glisten and glisten and glint.
As the long day lengthens and lingers and lasts,
And the parched earth throbs in the quivering heat,
And the breezes of morn change to withering blasts,
Hurling columns of dust down the deserted street,
My soul becomes weary with worry and work,
My hands become weary; each duty I shirk.
As the fireflies glitter and glimmer and glare,
In the soft, sweet calm of the twilight air.
And the whippoorwill calls from its woodland lair,
Sending its plaintiveness everywhere,
My soul is freed from its burden of care,
As the fireflies glitter and glitter and glare.
—Unit, of Minn. Magazine.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

A writer in the University of Minnesota Magazine in a philosophical mood,
gives us the following definition of what college spirit is not. In this is some
good food for reflection; so we print it entire—without criticism.
Much has been said about college spirit. To say exactly of what it consists is hard, but I am told by authorities that it does not consist:
1. In promiscuous yelling,—except when in the interest of the college
team or organization.
2. In whistling the fool's march. This march must have taken its name
from the whistler.
3. In an over indulgence of the faculty of politics to the detriment of
athletics and other student enterprises,
4. In getting "boozy" and "tearing things up."
5. In forever criticising faculty regulations and using no means but gas
and around-the-corner-mouthings to get them changed.
6. In talking always about the faults of the institution and never men tioning the good points. No college is perfect; if there were one such, Emerson, Hawthorne, Dana and Curtis would want to come to life so as to live in
the new "Brook-Farm"—without the farm work.
7. In filling the heads of the Freshmen with nonsense about the peculiarities of the professors.
8. In being more loyal to a particular faction than to your alma mater.
9. In supporting society so called, dances and blind tigers, to the exclusion of athletics, literary societies and college publications. The amount spent
by one man at a single dance will pay dues in the Athletic Association and subscribe for all the publications.

NOVEMBER 6, 1901.

No. 3.

METHOD IN READING.
S it possible to give a general answer, of any value, to the question, What
shall I read?
The question is not well answered by prescribing a list of books. This
does not allow for individual tastes and for special circumstances, and for that
reason can hardly lead to any valuable result; "Courses of reading" are seldom
followed with profit. Nor is it enough to say simply that one should read what
one finds interesting. This is true, but not the whole truth, for, out of the various things that may interest one, it is desirable to select the most important. Is
it possible to lay down any principles that may guide one in determining what,
at any given stage of intellectual progress, is most suitable to be read?
Most persons would probably agree that, to one who has general cultivation
.
In view, history is of such fundamental importance that it should, especially at
first, form the staple of reading. The mind is interested in facts earlier and
more easily than in abstract thoughts, and hence it is well to begin with history.
Moreover, many subjects cannot be understood without a competent historical
knowledge; no one can study art, literature, politics, philosophy intelligently,
unless he knows something of the development through which they have passed,
and the various conditons of society which, at different times have modified
them. In studying history, one is preparing oneself for the study of many
things. Further, the dispositions, intellectual and moral, which are cultivated
through historical studies are of highest value; "histories make men wise."
During the earlier years of one's self-education, the endeavor should be to gain
a competent knowledge of—at least—Greek, Roman, Mediaeval, English and
American history. In such reading care must be taken not to attempt to force
the memory to retain too much. The writing of abstracts is a valuable aid, and
frequent and patient review is indispensable.
The reading of imaginative literature should go on in connection with historical and biographical reading. One reason for combining th2 two is the
mental relief thus secured. Works of fiction are especially useful as recreation.
After prolonged and serious application, a good novel will restore tone and animation to the mind. Two things should be remembered in regard to novel
reading: first, that it ought to be kept in its place as recreation and not allowed
to usurp time needed for other purposes, and, second, that it should be confined
to books which are really worth one's while. Much time is wasted upon third
and fourth rate stories, which, if expended upon masterpieces, would yield far
more pleasure, as well as vastly more profit.

5

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

The glory of our English literature is in its poetry. This "feigned history" is as important an element of our mental life as actual history. Lord
Bacon well expresses the relation between the two. "Because the acts or events
of true history have not that magnitude which satisfieth the mind of man, poesy
feigneth acts and events greater and more heroical; because true history propoundeth the successes and issues of actions not so agreeable to the merits of
virtue a nd vice, therefore poetry feigns them more just in retribution, and more
according to revealed providence; because true history representeth acts and
events more ordinary and less interchanged, therefore poesy endueth them with
more rareness, and more unexpected and alternative variations." One should
begin with objective and narrative poetry rather than with that which is analytic
and reflective. The early ballads, the Canterbury Tales, Shakspere's histories
and comedies, Goldsmith, Gray, Burns, Scott, Tennyson's Idyls of the Kings,
Longfellow, Whittier—such poetry is more suitable to an unformed taste and
judgment than that of which Wordsworth may be cited as an example. Such
collections as the "Golden Treasury of Songs and Lyrics" are an excellent introduction to the study of poetry. At a later stage of one's growth, the profounder poen y becomes congenial; one learns to find pleasure in metaphysical
refinements and over-subtleties, like those of Robert Browning, which at first
would have been simply incomprehensible.
After a proper basis has been laid for it, what may be called philosophical
reading may be undertaken with profit. By this is meant works of theory and
criticism, which attempt to do more than narrate and describe, which seek to
make generalizations and to search into laws and causes. Every great series of
facts, whether of nature or of man, is capable of being treated both historically
and philosophically, that is, in the way of simple statement and narration, and
also with the design of accounting for the facts and getting at the truths and
laws involved in them. When the latter mode of treatment is adopted, it is
common to use the word philosophy—as we speak of the "philosophy of history," or the "philosophy of art." This department of literature should evidently be reserved until a suitable amount of knowledge has been acquired, and
the powers of reflection and speculation have been properly developed. One is
not qualified to judge the merits of a theory, or a generalization, until one has
become familiar with the facts upon which it rests. The range of possible
reading under this head is, of course, indefinitely wide. A person interested in
nature will naturally pass from simple observation and experiment to the speculative and theoretical aspects of his subject. One familiar with history and literary events and personages will enjoy works of criticism and generalization,
which seek to establish principles of taste, to deduce laws of progress, to compare different eras of civilization. The mental and moral sciences fall under this
category, and also works of political, social,.and theological science. One comes
to studies of this kind at a great advantage, if the mind has been generously
equipped with facts, and the imagination has been trained by familiarity with the
masters of fiction and poetry.
A threefold classification, such as has been suggested, may be of service to
one who is trying to outline a plan of reading with reference, not to acquisition

THE NEWS—LETTER.

3

in a specific field, but to general culture. History, as affording a basis of fact;
imaginative literature, as helping to develop the ideal faculty; philosophy, in a
broad sense, as coordinating and interpretating the phenomena of the world:—
these are the three interests which need to be kept in view, and to be brought
E. H. G.
into harmonious cooperation.

. MEMORIAL EXERCISES TO DR. ROWLAND.
N Saturday, October 26th, the lecture room of the Johns Hopkins physical
laboratory was filled by students and scholars, assembled to hear former
President Mendenhall of Worcester Polytechnic Institute deliver a eulogy
on the late Prof. Henry A. Rowland. Among those present were Mrs. Rowland
and other members of the late Professor's family, Mrs. Huntington Williams,
Dr. Carey T. Hutchinson of New York, and Dr. N. E. Dorsey of Washington,
who were formerly connected with the Johns Hopkins department of physics;
Dr. Wolfe of Washington; Dr. Stratton, the director of the National Bureau of
Standards, and Dr. Barker of Philadelphia. Former President Gilman had a
place in the front row.
President Remsen said, as he introduced Dr. Mendenhall:
"We have already given some expression to the thoughts and feelings Professor Rowland's death aroused in us. We were then, however, too much influenced by our new grief to look at his life work in the broadest way. Our expressions were rather those of personal emotions. We meant to hold a meeting
at which the fuller meaning of his life might be made clear to us. We are receding from him, and the increasing distance gives us clearer view. How great
he was and in what way only a physicist like himself can tell us."
Dr. Mendenhall was then introduced and commenced his address by a reference to Professor Rowland's originality.
"Many of his contemporaries,' he said, "excel him in the quantity of their
works; very, very few of them equal him in its quality. The full value of his
labors may be understood only in the great results to which its quality led other
workers whom his example had stimulated. A complete estimate would demand
reference to nearly all physical investigation of the last quarter of the old century. Quality was his admiration. By this test we will judge his achievements."
With a close knowledge of exact details Dr. Mendenhall then sketched the
development of Dr. Rowland's investigations from an early paper written as a
joke to the Scientific American at the age of 17. The latter part of the address
Was devoted to the personal side of the dead physicist. His characteristics, the
early aptitudes and preferences of the boy, his perseverance and dexterity in applying them under difficulties, the boldness and directness by which he reached
his later results, the severe candor with which he treated his own works and
everybody else's, his underlying kindness of heart, the full devotion with which
he pursued his objects all were outlined in a manner that aroused the highest
admiration of the audience.
After the address Dr. Remsen invited those present to go into one of the
nearby investigation rooms and look over the many inventions of the late
scientist.

REPRODUCTION OF THE ATHARVA-VEDA.
ROI-4'ESSOR Maurice Bloomfield is in possession of a newly-issued hook
which promises to throw much light on the manners and customs of our
Aryan ancestors many hundreds of years ago. It is a photographic
reproduction, prepared by Professor Bloomfield and Professor Richard Garbe of
Tubingen, of the oldest known manuscript of the Atharva-Veda, one of the
Vedic or sacred books of the Aryan nations. The "Atharva" is the collection
giving the charms, exorcisms, and incantations of the old religion. It tells
how to secure a sweetheart, maintain a happy family, control sickness, and
succeed in business; and it thus gives a most valuable glimpse into the life and
institutions of our oldest known progenitors.
The bringing to light of this volume is due mainly to Professor Von Roth,
of Germany. He realized the insufficiency and corruption of the first edition of
the Atharva; and it was by his energy that the present manuscript was discovered in Srinagar, Kashmir. Professor Roth left the manuscript at his death to
the University of Tubingen.
The manuscript contains about 275 pages of two sheets of birch hark each,
written in an indelible black ink, little faded in the 400 years since the manuscript was written. (The collection contained is, of course, many centuries
older.) Professor Bloomfield hoped that in time a version replacing the native
characters by their English equivalents may be printed, followed by a translation of the text.

DR. GILDERSLEEVE AND THE MEMORIAL VOLUME.

t

HE widespread and deeply appreciative tributes of the press on the occasion
of Dr. Basil L. Gildersleeve's seventieth birthday, October 23, are examples of high praise where it is due. Dr. Gildersleeve has combined more
than, perhaps, any other living American, the functions of the tremendously
erudite specialist, and of the broad minded man of letters. This idea of liberal
scholarship he has carried with him throughout his lengthy and many-sided
career.
Dr. Basil Lanneau Gildersleeve was born in Charleston, S. C., October 23,
1831. He took his A. M. at Princeton in 1852, after studying at Charleston
and Washington Jefferson Colleges. In 1856, after several years at Berlin,
Bonn, and Gottingen, he became Professor of Greek at the University of Virginia; and his connection there continued, with a break during his service in
the Civil War, until the foundation of the Johns Hopkins University in 1876.
Honors have showered upon Dr. Gildersleeve for many years, the latest
being the degree of I.,. L. D. presented him by Yale University. But of all
these recognitions, perhaps none has carried to him as much personal good-will
and esteem as will the Memorial Volume now under preparation by a number
of his former students.
This volume will be entitled: "Studies in Honor of Basil Lanneau Gildersleeve." It will contain some 400 pages, consisting of articles by thirty of his

THE NEWS—LETTER.

5

former students at Virginia and Johns Hopkins; and these articles will constitute not only a tribute to Dr. Gildersleeve, but a valuable addition to Greek
philology. Four hundred copies are to be printed by subscription. Dr. M. C.
Sutphen, whose unfortunate death occurred this summer, had charge of the
arrangements for the book. The present committee is composed of Dr. E. H.
Spieker, Dr.. Maurice Bloomfield, Dr. C. W. Emil Miller, Dr. Kirby F. Smith,
Dr. Christopher Johnston, Dr. B. J. Vos, and Dr H. L. Wilson.
On Dr. Gildersleeve's return from Yale, he was presented with a handsome
cathedral clock by the students of his department. The publication of the
Memorial Volume, however, will not take place until Christmas.
MEDAL FROM YALE.

Z

HE Johns Hopkins University last week received from Yale a beautiful
bronze medal, in commemoration of the late bicentennial celebration. In
speaking of the gift President Remsen said that all the leading universities and colleges which were represented in the exercises had received a similar
memorial. The medal was made by Tiffany & Co., N. Y. It is embedded in
a dark leather case, about four inches square, lined with Yale blue silk and
plush. The medal itself is two inches in diameter, and is of the finest workmanship.
On its face is the figure of a victorious Greek, returning in his war
chariot. In front of his restive steeds, a fair goddess waits to place on his brow
the wreath of laurel, Above this scence are the Latin words "Lux et Verztas."
On the other side are two Grecian torches, between which, in raised letters, is
the simple memorial inscription:
Universitas Yalensis
A. D. MDCCCCI
Concelebtat
Collegium Yalense
A. D. MDCCI Conditum.
X PRESIDENT Gilman's address on the second day of the Yale Bicentennial Celebration treated of the relation of Yale to letters and science. In
c- onclusion, he described the spirit of Yale as "living for others, not for
one's self, the greatest happiness in the utmost service." Dr. Welch, professor
of pathology at the Medical School, also spoke,tracing the development of medical progress by Yale professors and graduates. On this occasion, President
Remsen, Dr. Osier, and Dr. Gildersleeve were honored with the degree of
L. L. D., which has already been conferred by Yale upon three other members
of the Faculty—ex-President Gilman, the late Dr. Rowland, and Dr. Welch.

ALL ROOTERS OUT.
N November 16th, the first game for the Maryland Inter-Collegiate foot
ball championship will be played in Baltimore between Western Maryland College and Johns Hopkins. On our trophy-room wall is a space
just large enough for the championship banner; the team is going to try to cover
that space. The team has worked hard and conscientiously, "meds" and
scrubs are out; but so far the rooting has been woefully weak. Weak rooting
does not help bring banners to Hopkins; good, strong rooting is a great
encouragement to the players. Every loyal Hopkins man will be on hand at
both the Western Maryland and St. John's games to help the team struggle.
Every Hopkins man who wants to be called true to his colors must realize that
he is needed at the games. Everybody out, to demonstrate that the enthusiastic
spirit of the last two years is not dead, but dormant.

O

HE gymnasium building is the barometer indicating changes in the temperament, feelings, and conditions of Hopkins men. If trouble is brewing, the
first foam is generally seen in the gym -or cage; if victory is to be celebrated,
the cage is the place where the first yell is given. The locker-room,the cage, the
gymnasium proper are so intimately associated with Hopkins life that the mere
mention generally brings up clear visions !of some of the most i pleasant
incidents of the short three years here. It is also intimately connected with
some of the first impressions—which may not be so pleasant. All the idle
moments at one's command are put in at the gym; and its just in this point that

Z

THE NEWS-LETTER.
the weather indications are shown. If many men loaf around in citizen's garb,
instead of donning undress suits; if they saunter around with pipe in mouth,
and hands in pocket, passing time and criticisms regardless of the value of
either; if their only occupation is to knock,—then something is wrong somewhere. The atmosphere or the people is at fault. That it is not the atmosphere is shown by the notable lack of loafing this year. Very few men come
into the gym building now unless they go in for work. The apparatus upstairs
is being worked hard, the foot ball squad is fairly large, lacrosse and track men
are out, and altogether there is plenty of life all around. Where there is so
much scholastic activity as here, such a state of affairs in athletics is to be
highly commended. The atmosphere is apparently healthy for a general
development.

4 43T's strange I never see any class numerals on fellows over here." A
medical student at Hopkins, who received his A. B. at a large Northern
college, was heard to give expression to these remarks a few days ago.
When the matter is thought over, it does seem strange that within the last few
years the giving of numerals as athletic honors within the classes has been
abandoned. The practice must have been in vogue when the class of 1900 was
here, for many men of that class were seen to wear the red 1901 in "broad display on their manly chests," and on the jerseys of still older men is occasionally
seen the graduating year. Surely, a man who does good work for his class
ought to receive recognition as well as the fellow who is lucky enough to make
the 'Varsity. Where many men strive for few positions, the majority get left;
but why should not the classes remember that it is this majority who bring
victories on class day and rushes? Naughty-two has forgotten this. Think it
over, Juniors and Freshmen.

SENIOR FEED.

t

HE first "Feed" of the Class of '02 is to be held at the Johns Hopkins
Club on the evening of the 16th, after the Western Maryland College
game. Details may be learned from Ogle Marbury, '02. In this connection it is interesting to note a recent address of President Pritchett of the
Boston- "Tech.," in which he strongly advocated just such "stein and pipe"
gatherings, in contrast to the formal dress banquet.
President Pritchett believes in the democratic system of entertainment
found in German universities, where professors and students meet at the frequent "vereins," discussing problems or enjoying more general conversation.
Rich and poor alike gather in good fellowship, each man paying his own score
for beer and tobacco. Thus, says Dr. Pritchett, much sympathetic intercourse
is made possible between the students and also the professors; and he hopes
that his proposed inauguration of such meetings among college students in
Boston will cause a big improvement in college social life.
These free and informal "feeds" are a move in the right direction, one
which must be taken up in turn by '03. Every Hopkins man will welcome a

UNDERGRADUATE HAPPENINGS.

t

HE Class of 1902 has decided to present a large settee to the trophy-room.
It is now being made, and will completely fill one of the corners.

The Junior Class officers are: President, H. W. Plaggemeyer; Vice-President, R. C. Hoffman, Jr.; Secretary, J. T. Smith; Treasurer, F. Hazlehurst, Jr.;
Historian, R. S. Lanier; Poet, T. W. Glocker; Orator, J. B. G. Custis, Jr.;
Jester, 5, C. Hopper; Sergeant-at-arms, J. A. Houghton; Captain of Class Foot
Ball Team, F. C. Blauck; Manager, W. H. Matthai; Yell Committee: Lanier,
Bamberger, Pagon, Sandrock and Bird; Flag Committee, Tootle, Baetjer and
Hunley. The following men have been taken into the class organization: F.N.
Iglehart, from '94; Royalle Williams, Lehigh; J. M. Combs, University of
California.
J. S. Grasty has been elected by acclamation to the post of chief rooter,
and is endeavoring to instil into the minds of the Freshmen some slight knowledge of the Hopkins yells. Meetings for practice have been held in the cage,
and it is hoped that '04 will soon make some much-needed improvement in this
direction. They need it.
The first deba"e in the Senate on the benefits of the late strike was not a
shining success. After much talking on both sides, the decision was awarded
to the Ministry's team, which upheld the capitalists' view. The Juniors debated the same question with the same result. The Senior debaters have already
been announced in the NEWS LETTER. The Juniors were: Plaggemeyer,
Smith, Tootle, affirmative; Strayer, Glocker, Blum, negative,
The Freshman Class officers are as follows: President, E. D. Dickey; VicePresident, J. N. Numsen; Secretary, L. G. Wallis; Treasurer, J. R. B. Branch;
Historian, R. S. Opie; Poet, R. S. Licking; Sergeant-at-arms, S. C. Erlanger.
The class colors are black and red.
The strength of the present Freshman Class is 48, as against 55 for last
year. Noughty-three, however, has lost several men this fall, so that the
numbers are not far from equal.
An edict has been issued by the Musical Club's management, requiring all
prospective members of any club to deposit with the leader the sum of $3.00,
which is to be regarded as an advance payment of fines for absence and lateness
at rehearsals. These fines are at the rate of 50 cents for each rehearsal cut and
one cent for every minute late. The money is to be refunded at the end of the
season, less fines collected.

The Glee Club is practising a new Hopkins song, words by W. B. Carver,
to the tune of "Michael Roy." It is a lively marching song, and bids fair to
be the success of the season.
A new scientific organization has been formed, by name the Society of the
Diamond. It was started by a group of biological students, who, finding themselves unable to see some required object in the laboratory, adjourned to procure aid. Subsequent meetings have been held with great benefit. This asso
dation, which is semi-secret in character, is open to scientific students only.

UNIVERSITY NOTES.
N Thursday, Oct. 24, the marriage took place of Mr. Melvin Brandow, assistant librarian of the University, to Miss Ruth Boocock, of New Jersey.

O

Dr. J. M. West, of this city, who took his degree at the Medical School last
June, is about to start for Germany, where he will specialize at various leading
institutions in diseases of the throat.
Dr. Percy L. Kay, recently called to a position in the Treasury Department
of Porto Rico, is the third Hopkins graduate from the history and economics
department to hold a position at the Porto Rican Treasury. The other two are
Dr. J. H. Hollander, who was treasurer of the island, and Dr. T. S. Adams,
whose place Dr. Kay is taking.
Dr. Francisco del Valle, and Dr. Francisco del Valle, Jr., who are attending
courses in the department of history and economics, are graduates of the Institute of San Juan, Porto Rico; the former in 1867, the latter in 1894. In addition, Dr. del Valle is an M. D. of the College of Medicine, Cadiz, 1872, while his
son took his D. D. S. at the Baltimore College of Dental Surgery, and has also
studied law at the University of Maryland.
J. E. Routh, 1900, has been awarded the $250 prize offered by the Century
Magazine for the best essay written by a graduate of any American college or
university. The title of the essay was "Huxley as a Literary Man." Mr.
Routh is at present a graduate student in mathematics and physics.
A letter has been received from the Johns Hopkins Club of the Middle
West, announcing that its second annual session and banquet will be held at
the Hotel Baltimore, Kansas City, Mo., on Friday, November 29. Those finding it possible to attend will notify the secretary, Dr. Chas. Lee Smith, Liberty,
Mo. The officers of the club, which numbers more than 60 members, are as
follows: President, Dr. F. W. Blackmar, University of Kansas; secretary, Dr.
Chas. Lee Smith, William Jewell College, Mo.; vice-presidents, Prof. J. C. Futrall, University of Arkansas; Dr. A. G. Leonard, of Iowa, and Dr. J. White,
University of Nebraska, These officers constitute the Executive Committee.

GALLAUDET, 12—HOPKINS, 0.

t

HE result of our game with Gallaudet was no more than could be expected
with the crippled team which represented Hopkins aturday before last.
Blanck could not be in the game on account of his lame foot. Hill was not
with the team, and Stone was also unable to play. With these three men out of
the game Hopkins did well to hold her silent opponents down to twelve points,
which she did very creditably.
Sharretts kicked off, and Gallaudet was downed with the ball on her fiveyard line. Right at the start Gallaudet showed some superb team work, as her
interference was well nigh invincible, and quickness in starting remarkable.
Erickson made the first dash through left tackle, leaving thirty yards behind him
at the finish; and after an effective mass-play, added ten yards around right end.
By alternating end plays with marvelous success, Gallaudet lanced the pigskin
in the coveted position after six minutes of play. Geilfuss kicked goal.
Sharretts kicked off for Hopkins, and Andree advanced the oval to the fifteen yard line. After two long end runs by Erickson and Andree, Gallaudet
lost the ball for holding; but the Black and Blue were unsuccessful in their attempts at tackle through tackle, so Sayler punted, and by making a touchback
the silent eleven returned the ball from their twenty five yard line Sharretts
caught it and carried it twenty yards on the jump. Then Hopkins unfortunately
lost the oval on downs; and after good gains through guard and around the
ends, Gallaudet tried a drop kick for goal, but failed and Hopkins downed the
ball on her twenty yard line. The Black and Blue now being unable to tear off
more than a yard or two of the required five, Sayler punted. Gallaudet was
forced to do likewise, soon after Sayler returned the kick; and the first half
ended with the ball on Gallaudet's forty yard line.
Gallaudet started the second half with a beautiful kick, and Hopkins
downed the ball on her three yard line. Sayler immdiately punted. After a
couple of good gains through tackle and end Gallaudet was penalized ten yards
for holding, and soon after tried a drop kick. A touchback being made, Sayler
kicked from the twenty-five yard line, and the ball was downed iu the center of
the field. Now with her excellent interference and speedy rushes through the
line and around the ends, Gallaudet soon had the ball behind the goal post.
Geilfuss again kicked goal.

11

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Sharretts kicked off, and after a short gain of five yards the mutes lost the
oval on downs. Hopkins, rather than do likewise, kicked. Thus the second
half ended with the ball in Gallaudet's possession on her fifty yard line.
As was stated the Hopkins team was not its real self in this game. Besides
the three men who were not in it at all, Whipple was knocked out right at the
start. The Black and Blue did well in all their kicks and punts, but showed an
alarming tendency to tackle high, thus allowing their opponents to gain more
ground than they should have. This is mainly on account of the practice in the
Cage, where low tackling would probably produce disastrous results with such
narrow space between the walls. Our fellows were at first rather ineffective at
breaking the opposing interference, but in the second half they did better; and
the line held together wonderfully well against superior weight. The rooting
of Gallaudet was in itself a feature of the game. Actions speak louder than
words. The line up was as follows:

HAVERFORD, 5; HOPKINS, 0
T would have done every rooter's heart good to have seen the great game
which Hopkins put up against Haverford College last Saturday. A pretty
individual play in the shape of a goal from the field was the sole thing

what stuff was in it by forcing Haverford to punt after the second scrimmage.
Towards the end of the half, we rushed the ball down the field by fast, snappy

Like a drowning man grasping at a straw, Haverford braced, and after

3

1Z

THE NEWS—LETTER.

Sayler, and Blanck smashed the line only to stick, the ball went over to Haverford on downs. The oval had been worked along to that point for a distance of
65 yards only through the greatest determination and effort by every man, and
then to lose it when almost on the goal line—it did, indeed, seem mighty hard
luck. Haverford punted out of danger immediately, and a moment later the
first half ended.
According to a statement made by one of Haverford's men, she fully expected to pile up a score of about 25 points on "Johnny Hopkins." They were
clearly outplayed in the first half, and only by a heroic effort at the last moment
did they prevent Hopkins from scoring. To say that they were both surprised
and piqued would be stating the case very mildly.
In the second half Haverford started in with a grand rush, but Hopkins
continued to be strictly in the game, and almost invariably the home team was
forced to punt for fear of losing the ball on downs. After twelve minutes play,
Haverford's end runs and line rushes seemed to be more effective, and the ball
was advanced to Hopkins 15 yards, which was the nearest she ever got to our
goal line. Then "Johnny" realized that something must be done, and in the
next scrimmage Faris took a kindly hold on the back of the runner's jersey and
snatched him back for just eight yards. The band of Haverford rooters, 250
strong, sent up a deafening yell of encouragement to their team, and the little
hand of Hopkins enthusiasts, six strong, piped out a feeble "Hullabaloo."
Their voices were a little the worse for wear by that time. Captain Grant saw
plainly that he could never carry the ball over Hopkins' goal line, and he
ordered the next best thing. Drinker dropped back to the 30 yard line, and a
moment later received a pretty pass in just the proper place. The ball dropped,
and, as it touched the ground, his toe caught it, and between the posts she
twirled, giving Haverford five points and the game. Hopkins never lost heart,
and a few minutes before the end of the half, she again had the ball on Haverford's 15 yard line. Another reverse of fortune came, however, and she lost the
oval on downs.
In such a battle royal it is difficult to ascribe special honors to any one man.
Every player deserves a hearty slap on the back, and the exclamation, "pretty
work, great work, old man!" Captain Gillespie was naturally disappointed
after such a hard fight, hut both he and Coach Dickson agree in saying that the
team played a truly great game. Next Saturday, Delaware College is to he
played at Wilmington. We are going up to win, and we want a big band of
rooters to see us do it. The teams played as follows:

LEC TURES.

HE courses of lectures in science and literature, designed primarily for pub
lic school teachers, began on Saturday of last week.

ORIENTAL SEMINARY,—Dr. Foote will give a course of lectures on the
"Literature of the Old Testament," based on the English Bible. Dr. Haupt
will deliver,the introductory lecture, on "How we got our Bible," in the Dillman Room, Wednesday, at 5 o'clock.
The lectures on Public Speaking, given by Mr. S. A. King, M. A., of the
University of London, will be continued on November 6, 11, 15, and 18, at 5
o'clock, in McCoy Hall. Mr. King's first lecture was given Monday.
On Wednesday, the 6th, Dr. Jeffrey R. Brackett, president of the City Supervisors of Charities, will begin a course of lectures on "The Development of
Legislation and Custom Touching Charity and Correction in the United States
and England." The lectures will be held in Levering Hall.
Y. M. C. A. NOTES.
HE courses in Bible Study are in full progress. A class for graduate students meets every Saturday morning at 8.30 to consider special topics selected by the committee in charge, which consists of Mr. D. B. Easter, L.
G. Barret, F. H. Getman. Enrollment, 24. A course for Seniors in the "Acts
and Epistles," led by Mr. J. Gresham Machen, meets at 1 P. M. Wednesdays,
and has an enrollment of 6. The Junior class is under the leadership of Mr.
Horace C. Gillespie, and numbers 7, meeting at firesent at 8.30 A. M., Wednesdays, to consider the same topics followed by the Seniors. This duplication of
the courses results from the fact that there was no Junior Bible class last year.
The Freshman Bible class is in two groups, on account of conflict of hours:
one, led by C. K. Edmunds, meets Thursdays at 10 A. M.; the other, led by R.
S. Licking, meets Thursdays at noon. The enrollment in these two groups is
9, and Sharman's "Life of Christ" is used.
The regular weekly devotional meeting on Tuesday, Oct. 28, was led by
Mr. Don 0. Shelton, International Secretary, who gave a very stimulating Bible
reading in Phillipians.
Mr. A. B. Williams, Jr.,(Yale), Intercollegiate Secretary for the East, addressed the meeting on Tuesday, Nov. 3, and was also present at a conference
of workers Tuesday night at the home of the General Secretary.
The Mission Study class numbers 9, meeting every other Sunday afternoon
at 3.30. Under the direction of Dr. Ballagh, it is proving exceedingly interesting and helpful.
The week beginning Sunday, November 10, will be observed in common
with all religious bodies throughout the country as a "Week of Prayer." There
will be a meeting Sunday afternoon at 4.30, and every day during the week

The number of students registered at Harvard this year is 4043.
More young men are studying medicine than are studying law and theology
combined.
Princeton has recently been presented with $100,000 for the erection of a new
dormitory.
The Freshman Class at Harvard numbers 553, and at Princeton the entering
class has 400 members. In both of these institutions these numbers surpass all
previous records.
At the McMaster University games A. E. Haydon broke the Canadian Col
lege record for the pole vault by clearing 9 feet 11 inches.
The oratorical cpntest for the Founder's medal at Vanderbilt University
was won by a Chinaman His subject was: "The Miracle of ' the Twentieth
Century"—the regeneration of China.
The Athletic Association of the University of Colorado has constructed a
fine athletic field 684x242 feet, with a quarter mile track, a grand stand for one
thousand spectators, bath rooms for athletes—all at the foot of a beautiful
mountain.
The University of Pennsylvania has taken the preliminary steps necessary
for the erection of a new medical laboratory, which in point of completeness and
equipment, it is claimed, will be in advance of any similar building now in existence in this country or in Europe.

LESSON yr.

See the Parrot in his Cage, children! Isn't he just beautiful? Put your
little Fist into the Cage, Johnnie, and try to Pull a feather from his Tail. Don't
scream so frightfully, my Boy: Polly only wanted to Show his Teeth. There,
there, stop crying, and I will give you a Chaw of Gum. When you have finished
chewing it, Send it to the Dog for a while, and then Susie will be glad to Chew
it for three Days. Now isn't that lovely?

MOODS.

As the dewdrops glisten and glint and glint,
In the shafts of the light from the eastern hills,
And the air is laden with clover and mint,
Wafted from fields where the mockbird
Where the mockbird warbles and trills and trills,
My heart is elate with the morn, and thrills
All a-quiver with hope and joy without stint,
As the dewdrops glisten and glisten and glint.
As the long day lengthens and lingers and lasts,
And the parched earth throbs in the quivering heat,
And the breezes of morn change to withering blasts,
Hurling columns of dust down the deserted street,
My soul becomes weary with worry and work,
My hands become weary; each duty I shirk.
As the fireflies glitter and glimmer and glare,
In the soft, sweet calm of the twilight air.
And the whippoorwill calls from its woodland lair,
Sending its plaintiveness everywhere,
My soul is freed from its burden of care,
As the fireflies glitter and glitter and glare.
—Unit, of Minn. Magazine.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

A writer in the University of Minnesota Magazine in a philosophical mood,
gives us the following definition of what college spirit is not. In this is some
good food for reflection; so we print it entire—without criticism.
Much has been said about college spirit. To say exactly of what it consists is hard, but I am told by authorities that it does not consist:
1. In promiscuous yelling,—except when in the interest of the college
team or organization.
2. In whistling the fool's march. This march must have taken its name
from the whistler.
3. In an over indulgence of the faculty of politics to the detriment of
athletics and other student enterprises,
4. In getting "boozy" and "tearing things up."
5. In forever criticising faculty regulations and using no means but gas
and around-the-corner-mouthings to get them changed.
6. In talking always about the faults of the institution and never men tioning the good points. No college is perfect; if there were one such, Emerson, Hawthorne, Dana and Curtis would want to come to life so as to live in
the new "Brook-Farm"—without the farm work.
7. In filling the heads of the Freshmen with nonsense about the peculiarities of the professors.
8. In being more loyal to a particular faction than to your alma mater.
9. In supporting society so called, dances and blind tigers, to the exclusion of athletics, literary societies and college publications. The amount spent
by one man at a single dance will pay dues in the Athletic Association and subscribe for all the publications.
